TRAP laws restricting access to abortion are unconstitutional.
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

The right to an abortion is under attack across the country, including Virginia. For years, legislators have added more and more restrictions, such as unnecessary licensing regulations, waiting periods, and hospital requirements.

This week, the ACLU of Virginia served as local counsel in a case with the Center for Reproductive Rights on behalf of a group of abortion care providers — including Whole Woman’s Health Alliance, Falls Church Healthcare Center and the Virginia League for Planned Parenthood — to fight these unnecessary restrictions in court.

We heard four days of testimony from plaintiffs, experts, regulators, and physicians in this federal trial. Here are a few highlights from their testimony:

  • Physician-only laws requiring a licensed physician to perform even first-trimester abortions are unnecessary. Advanced practice clinicians, like nurse practitioners, currently routinely perform miscarriage management, which involves similar or identical procedures as abortions.
  • Mandatory waiting periods cause delays in care — delays which make abortions less safe, not more.
  • Women and people seeking abortions are competent to make decisions about their own bodies. The Two-Trip Mandatory Delay law requires doctors to give patients an ultrasound, but true informed consent means freedom from external coercion or manipulation.
  • Abortions are safer than most outpatient procedures. Colonoscopies are ten times riskier than abortions, yet abortions are much more highly regulated.

Targeted restrictions on abortion providers, known as TRAP laws, are medically unnecessary and designed to make it more difficult to access safe, legal abortions. They are unconstitutional, and we’ll continue to fight them so all of us can have freedom and agency over our own bodies.

Thanks for sticking with us,

Nicole Tortoriello
The Secular Society Women’s Rights Advocacy Counsel
